awd_titl_txt: RUI: Study of Small Molecule Activation by Molybdenum Enzymes using Computational Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Dalia Rokhsana of Whitman College is supported by an award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry to investigate the reactivity of molybdenum-based enzymes, bacterial proteins that catalyze water-splitting reactions to produce hydrogen gas.  Hydrogen is an important "green" energy source for fuel cells, propulsion systems, and combustion engines.  Rokhsana and her group are using state-of-the-art computational chemistry and molecular modeling techniques to understand how the protein active site controls structure, function, specificity, and reactivity. This research has potential applications to the biomimetic design and optimization of large-scale hydrogen gas production. The project is supporting undergraduate student engagement at this primarily undergraduate institution.  These students co-author scientific papers, and make presentations at national meetings and regional conferences.  External collaborations with leading computational scientists enhance the integration of scientific discovery with student education, in keeping with the teacher-scholar model promoted at Whitman College. Problems based on the research are integrated with coursework in computational chemistry and biochemistry.  

One chemical functions of biological systems is the activation of inert small molecules under ambient conditions. Understanding the molecular mechanism of these processes is a challenging areas at the interface of biology and chemistry.  In this project, Rokhsana and her group are focusing on a diverse family of molybdenum enzymes that catalyze oxo-transfer to interconvert various substrates (carbon monoxide, sulfite, arsenite, etc.) into products, while splitting water into protons and electrons. This research focuses on a poorly-understood bimetallic [Mo-S-Cu] active site of a Mo-enzyme, CO dehydrogenase. The first aim is to investigate the composition of the active site as a function of redox-, spin-, and protonation-states. The second aim is to characterize geometric and electronic structures of intermediates and transition states during the non-reversible, catalytic transformation of carbon monoxide into carbon dioxide.  A computational approach is necessary due to the lack of direct and unambiguous information about intermediates from experiments. Rokhsana and her group are utilizing realistic quantum mechanical (QM) and extended quantum mechanical/molecular mechanical (QM/MM) models to systematically and comprehensively investigate the effect of protein environment on the geometric and electronic structure of the active site, and understand how the inner coordination sphere and outer protein environment control and tune metalloenzyme function. This work may providing insights into the overall catalytic mechanism of CO oxidation, with application to molecular engineering of biomimetic systems for the water splitting reaction.  The project is immersing undergraduate students in comprehensive and complementary bioinorganic and computational chemistry research involving state-of-the-art modeling and simulation techniques.  The new course is helping meet the considerable demand for research opportunities requested by students at Whitman College, and facilitating new collaborations and engagement with the broader chemistry community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF WHITMAN COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
The molybdenum oxo-transferases (CO dehydrogenase, sulfite oxidase, arsenite oxidase) are particularly interesting due to their unique ability to split water molecules while converting various small molecules (such as CO, sulfite, arsenite, nitrate, etc.). The reaction our group focuses on (conversion of carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide in water) is analogous to hydrogen gas production via the water gas-shift reaction. Our research is relevant to the production of protons and electrons from the water-splitting process, which is an area of intense investigation in biological photosynthesis.

Small molecule transformations are chemically challenging under ambient conditions. Therefore, understanding how these transformations occur will play a critical role in developing alternative green energy catalysts for vital environmental, biomedical, and industrial processes. In addition, using a validated large quantum mechanical model from our work will improve the efficiency and accuracy of future simulations of diverse biological systems.

Through our work, we have addressed the factors affecting the structure of the active site and the mechanism of CO conversion in CO dehydrogenase. We reevaluated the substrate oxidation to carbon dioxide or bicarbonate product. We found some unique intermediates that were not considered in earlier studies, altering the energetics of the overall oxidation process drastically (to be published). Using similar computational strategies, we generated a large quantum mechanical model for Sulfite Oxidase (SO) enzyme and validated this model using experimental data (structure and reduction potential). Various protonation states of active site bases (like tyrosine and histidine) and the molybdenum-coordinated equatorial oxygen-ligand (oxo, hydroxo, and water) were considered in developing robust, working models for these enzymes. Using the validated SO model, we have addressed the mutational impact of crucial residues at the active site. 

Given that all Mo-enzymes display similar reactivity but with varied substrate and inner coordination spheres, we promote our work as the groundwork for future studies in understanding the similarities and differences among the members of this metalloenzyme family. In addition, understanding how a class of Mo-enzymes utilizes standard accessories (such as cofactors and metals) to split water molecules will provide the means to develop rationally-designed model complexes which mimic biological Mo-enzyme chemistry. 

This work immersed five Whitman undergraduate students in comprehensive and complementary bioinorganic and computational chemistry research involving quantum mechanical methods. It allowed students to present their work at the American Chemical Society National Meeting, the Murdock College Science Research Conference, and the Whitman Undergraduate Conference. We hope to publish two peer-reviewed publications with student co-authors (manuscript in preparation). These research projects met the considerable demand for research opportunities for Whitman undergraduate students. They enhanced the integration of the PI's scientific discovery and educational activities, helping to enrich her courses in computational chemistry and biochemistry by bringing in real-life scientific problems and solutions from bioinorganic chemistry. Through this work, the PI and her students stayed connected to the broader bioinorganic chemistry community. The PI was able to secure additional funding from a private donor to create a 24-person computational chemistry lab space and upgrade the local computational servers at Whitman, providing numerous research opportunities to the other members of the Whitman community.


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Dalia R Biswas

Image
  • The large quantum mechanical model (259 atoms) for the active site in Sulfite Oxidase captures all important interactions at/around the active site vital for its function.
    Dalia Biswas
    Copyrighted
    Dalia R Biswas
    Active site model of sulfite oxidase
